THE MERCANTILE AGENCY REFERENCE BOOK FOR THE BRITISH PROVINCES ; CONTAINING RATINGS OF THE PRINCIPAL MERCHANTS, TRADERS, AND MANUFACTURERS IN THE CANADAS, NOVA SCOTIA, NEW BRUNSWICK, NEW- FOUNDLAND, AND PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND. 1866. YOL. III. MONTREAL AND TORONTO : PUBLISHED ANNUALLY BY DUN, WIMAN & CO. 1866. Entered, according to Act of the Provincial Parliament, in the year one thousand eight hundred and sixty-six, by E. Wiman, in the Office of the Registrar of the Province of Canada. MONTREAL: Printed by M. Longmoore & Co., 67 Great St. James Street. PREFACE "We again have the pleasure of presenting our subscrib- ers with another volume of The Mercantile Agency Reference Book. The present issue will be found much more complete than any ever before published. Not only is there a large increase in the number of localities and names reported, but the markings have all been thoroughly reconsidered and based upon full and detailed information up to the latest dates. There is not a name in the immense number which the book contains but has been the subject of recent special and close investigation. What long experience, a large investment of capital, a well-trained staff, and over a thousand intelligent and able correspondents have accomplished, is herein contained; and though misapprehensions and inaccuracies are inevi- table in a work of this character and magnitude, we pre- sent the result with a great deal of confidence. In the main we believe it will be a fair guide to all dispensers of credit; certainly, it will aid conclusions and materially assist all who occupy that position. It must always be borne in mind that The Reference Book is offered only as an aid for immediate reference, and where prompt decision is required. As a basis for large and continuous transactions, full and complete in- formation should be had. This information we shall be at all times happy to supply. Montreal and Toronto, ? August, 1866. $ TERMS OF SUBSCRIPTION. JQtnsT, WIMAN & 00. haying prepared a Reference Book of names of business men in the British Provinces, with ratings for the service of their subscribers, and the use of the same being needed by us as an aid in determining the safety of our credit business, we, the undersigned, do hereby employ the said Dun, Wiman & Co. to place in our keeping, for the term of one year, a printed copy of said Reference Book, above referred to, for our confidential use, and for which we will pay in advance dollars, and at the expiration of one year from date, return the said book to said Dun, WlMAN & Co. — ; i86 KEY PECUNIARY STRENGTH. Inquire at our Office. * * This embraces not only those of questionable credit, but also those whose business and investments render it difficult to rate them satisfactorily to ourselves. We therefore prefer, in justice to these, to give our detailed report. The first column is intended to represent, as nearly as the scale will admit, the worth of a person,— not only capital in business, but all property in possession above indebtedness. It has no relation to the second column, except so far as capital or property is a qualification for credit. All who are worth less than $2000 are left blank in this column. The markings in the second column are higher or lower, (as compared with pecuniary resources,) according to personal or business qualifications, the nature, hazard and extent of busi- ness, &c.
